importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article highlights the ongoing issue of poor air quality in New Delhi during the Diwali festival, which occurs annually and exacerbates pollution levels.
The start date of the Diwali festival, during which fireworks are traditionally set off, marks the beginning of increased pollution in New Delhi and surrounding regions.
The end date of Diwali celebrations, after which the festival concludes, still contributes to lingering pollution as fireworks and related emissions persist.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from October 18 to 23 marks the Diwali festival, during which fireworks increase pollution and air quality deteriorates significantly in New Delhi and neighboring areas.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi’s air quality reached a dangerously high level of 442 on the AQI during Diwali, the highest in the world according to IQAir, due to fireworks and other pollution sources.
PM2.5 levels in New Delhi were over 59 times higher than the World Health Organization’s recommended annual guideline, posing serious health risks to residents.
India’s Supreme Court allowed limited use of 'green crackers' for three hours on Sunday and Monday, but widespread violations led to illegal fireworks use.
The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) classified the air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350, indicating hazardous conditions.
New Delhi and neighboring regions face chronic winter smog due to cold air trapping pollution from traffic, industry, agriculture, and construction.
India's capital has previously experienced extreme smog events, such as a deadly week-long pollution surge in November 2024 with AQI exceeding 1,700.
Lahore, Pakistan, recorded an AQI of 234, the second most polluted major city globally, due to air pollution from Indian Punjab and agricultural fires.
Pakistani authorities have implemented emergency measures, including anti-smog guns and restrictions on farm fires and polluting vehicles, to counter transboundary pollution.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the Diwali festival in October 2025, New Delhi experienced one of the worst air pollution episodes globally, with its air quality index reaching 442 due to fireworks, traffic, industry, and agriculture. PM2.5 levels were over 59 times the WHO's recommended annual limit, making the air highly hazardous. Although India’s Supreme Court permitted limited use of low-emission 'green crackers,' widespread violations led to increased pollution. The Central Pollution Control Board classified the air as 'very poor,' and the Ministry of Earth Sciences predicted continued poor conditions. The crisis is exacerbated by winter smog, with New Delhi and neighboring regions, including Lahore, Pakistan, affected by transboundary pollution from agricultural fires in Indian Punjab. The situation underscores the urgent need for regional cooperation and effective pollution mitigation measures.
title: Diwali provokes ‘hazardous’ alert over New Delhi air quality
